comment_data.body: Forgot to paste the [link to the PoC](https://github.com/bspammer/vimcryption). Here is the site from where I took the code for [`utf_isvalid`](http://etutorials.org/Programming/secure+programming/Chapter+3.+Input+Validation/3.12+Detecting+Illegal+UTF-8+Characters/)

> I've stumbled across this interesting PoC that exploits Vim's non-standard implementation of UTF-8. And I'm currently investigating ways to fix this.

One could start implementing a newer version of Unicode. UTF-8 is encoded in `1` to `4` bytes. Vim still uses up to `6`. 

Testing `utf_isvalid(input)` with `input={x,0}` and `0x00 < x< 0x80` gives no result.

@oni-link I'm not proposing to use that code, it was the first thing I've found and there where a couple of references to it. I wanted some sort of litmus test. (I shudder a bit at the idea that some people might actually have this code running in production‚Ä¶). Anyway, I'd rather not have yet another implementation that will almost certainly be wrong in subtle ways again but something that has been well tested.

See https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/5149 for some related discussion. tl;dr seems that a PR adding some sort of support for utf8proc (or a similar library) would be welcome. (thanks to jamessan for issue reference).
@brcolow I was looking at utf8proc last night as well. I will play around with this a little. The idea of making this replace the ad-hoc UTF-8 implementation from Vim is quite appealing :)

The behavior of overlong control chars are also interesting, they are printed as their (invalidly) decoded value, so an overlong NUL is displayed as `<00>`. This is confusing as this notation is also used for invalid utf-8 bytes (well, that is correctly identified as invalid), such as `<ff>` for the raw byte `\xff`. I suppose the correct display would be to show all bytes in an overlong sequence individually as `<xx>`
I'll be playing around with utf8proc in Neovim here: https://github.com/raichoo/neovim/tree/utf8

After some initial hacking this seems to work rather nicely. Anyone up to take a look at some of the stuff I'm doing? This is really just a hack by now but having a couple more eyeballs and braincells on the issue might help :)

Just a side question.

While tampering with displaying characters, do you think it would be possible to centralize all the needed code which just transforms unprintable characters to the `<00>` form into a separate header file as a standalone header-only library?

I've already come across few use cases in some projects, when it was desirable to show them. And because Vim/Neovim already implements it quite well and users are used to it, it would make sense to reuse the code.
Yes, nothing has changed regarding this.

>  it would be nice to have a standard conforming implementation of UTF-8 in Neovim.

And indeed we have now bundled utf8proc and will be -- incrementally -- leveraging it for standard-compliant Unicode handling. Work is on-going and need not be tracked here.
